Sentence.sentence: Unfortunately, the current low prices for oil, gas, and coal may provide little incentive for research to find even cheaper substitutes for those fuels.
To promote sales of its products by lowering prices.
There is strong evidence that both innovation and adoption of cleaner technology are strongly encouraged by higher fossil fuel prices.

The recent discovery of the giant Zohr gas field off the Egyptian coast will eventually have impact on pricing in the Mediterranean region and Europe, and there is significant development potential in many other places, notably Argentina.

The reasoning behind this saying is that low oil prices discourage investment in new production capacity, eventually shifting the oil supply curve backward and bringing prices back up as existing oil fields—which can be tapped at relatively low marginal cost—are depleted.
The reason is that when carbon is priced, those emissions reductions that are least costly to implement will happen first.
The prices of coal are low as a result of over-supply and decreasing demand.
The hope is that the success of COP 21 opens the door to future international agreement on carbon prices.
The dynamic adjustment to low oil prices may, however, be different this time around.
The current low fossil fuel price environment will thus certainly delay the energy transition from fossil fuel to clean energy sources.
The North American shale gas boom has resulted in record low prices there.
Setting the right carbon price will therefore efficiently align the costs paid by carbon users with the true social opportunity cost of using carbon.
Progress in the development of renewables could be fragile, however, if fossil fuel prices remain low for long.
Pricing carbon proves the most economical way to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.
Policymakers should not allow low energy prices to derail the clean energy transition.
Oil prices have dropped by over 60% since June 2014.
Oil prices are expected to remain lower for longer.
Notwithstanding important recent progress in developing renewable fuel sources, low fossil fuel prices could discourage further innovation in, and adoption of, cleaner energy technologies.
Natural gas and coal—also fossil fuels—have similarly seen price declines that look to be long-lived.
In order to maximize global welfare, every country's carbon pricing should reflect not only the purely domestic damage from emissions, but also the damage to foreign countries.

In addition, other factors are putting downward pressure on oil prices: change in the strategic behavior of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries, the projected increase in Iranian exports, the scaling-down of global demand ( ' , especially from emerging markets), the long-term drop in petroleum consumption in the United States, and some displacement of oil by substitutes.
If not corrected by the appropriate carbon price, low fossil fuel prices are not accurately signaling to markets the true social profitability of clean energy.

Higher fossil fuel prices prove to be conducive to innovation and application of cleaner technologyIf fossil fuel prices remain low for a long time, it may lead to higher emissions of greenhouse gases.
Futures markets, which show only a modest recovery of prices to around $60 a barrel by 2019, support this view.
Fossil fuel prices are likely to stay low for long.
Economic reasoning shows that the least expensive way for each country is to put a price on carbon emissions.

Direct subsidies to research and development have been adopted by some governments but are a poor substitute for a carbon price: they do only part of the job, leaving in place market incentives to over-use fossil fuels and thereby add to the stock of atmospheric greenhouse gases without regard to the collateral ( ' , 附带的) costs.
Coal prices also are low, owing to over-supply and the scaling-down of demand, especially from China, which burns half of the world's coal.
Coal and natural gas are mainly used for electricity generation, whereas oil is used mostly to power transportation, yet the prices of all these energy sources are linked.

By raising relative demand for clean energy sources, a carbon price would also help align the market return to clean-energy innovation with its social return, spurring the refinement of existing technologies and the development of new ones.
Action to restore appropriate price incentives, notably through corrective carbon pricing, is urgently needed to lower the risk of irreversible and potentially devastating effects of climate change.
A tax on upstream carbon sources is one easy way to put a price on carbon emissions, although some countries may wish to use other methods, such as emissions trading schemes.
A number of factors are driving down the global oil prices not just for now but in the foreseeable future.
A commonly held view in the oil industry is that the best cure for low oil prices is low oil prices.
With fertilizer prices jumping nearly 50% per metric ton over the last year in some places, human waste is an attractive, and often necessary, alternative.
The House bill would authorize the secretary of health and human services to negotiate drug prices in Medicare and Medicaid.

Medical spending, which typically rises faster than wages and the overall economy, is propelled by two things: the high prices charged for medical services in this country and the volume of unnecessary care delivered by doctors and hospitals, which often perform a lot more tests and treatments than a patient really needs.
Contrary to analysts' doubts, the author believes drug prices may be lowered through negotiation.
And the head-to-head competition might give them a strong incentive to lower their prices, perhaps by accepting slimmer profit margins or demanding better deals from providers.

Saying they can no longer ignore the rising prices of health care, some of the most influential medical groups in the nation are recommending that doctors weigh the costs, not just the effectiveness of treatments, as they make decisions about patient care.
Just half a dozen holiday-makers have reached orbit since then, for similarly astronomical price tags.
Given the high price of room and board and the closeness of the school to his family, he chose to live at home and worked between 30 and 40 hours a week while taking a full class schedule.
5 million worth of young Bison that will be raised according to its grass-fed protocols, with a guaranteed purchase price.

sameAnalysis.part_name: 这些名词均有"价格，费用"之意。
sameAnalysis.word_list: charge, price, fee, fare, cost, expense
means: charge ： 指提供服务时索取的费用，也指货物的价格、价钱。
price ： 指商品在市场出售的价格，尤指卖方对商品所提出的单价。比喻意义指付出的代价。
fee ： 指上学、求医以及找律师等付的费用，还可指会费、借书费等。
fare ： 侧重指旅行时所付的车、船费等费用。
cost ： 指生产某东西的成本，也泛指商品的价格，可与price换用。
expense ： 常指实际支付的费用总数额，有时也指钱的花费。

pric价值,估价+e→n.价格, 价钱, 代价 v.给……定价

entry.def: The price of something is the amount of money that you have to pay in order to buy it.

example.ex: ...a sharp increase in the price of petrol...
They expected house prices to rise...

entry.def: The price that you pay for something that you want is an unpleasant thing that you have to do or suffer in order to get it.

example.ex: Slovenia will have to pay a high price for independence...
example.tran: 斯洛文尼亚将为独立付出巨大的代价。

example.ex: There may be a price to pay for such relentless activity, perhaps ill health or even divorce...
example.tran: 这样没命地工作可能要付出代价，也许是健康受损，甚至是离婚。

entry.def: If something is priced at a particular amount, the price is set at that amount.

example.ex: The shares are expected to be priced at about 330p...
example.tran: 这些股票的价格可能会定在330便士左右。

example.ex: Digital priced the new line at less than half the cost of comparable mainframes...
example.tran: Digital公司新产品的定价比同类主机的一半还要低。

entry.def: If you want something at any price, you are determined to get it, even if unpleasant things happen as a result.
entry.tran: 不惜任何代价；不计后果

example.ex: If they wanted a deal at any price, they would have to face the consequences...
example.tran: 如果他们无论如何都想达成交易，他们就得承担其后果。

example.ex: We obviously want to see the hostages home, but not at any price.
example.tran: 我们显然也希望看到人质回家，但并不是不惜任何代价。

entry.def: If you can buy something that you want at a price, it is for sale, but it is extremely expensive.

example.ex: Most goods are available, but at a price.
example.tran: 大多数商品都有售，但是价格极高。

entry.def: If you get something that you want at a price, you get it but something unpleasant happens as a result.

example.ex: Theismann's precious information came at a price, however.
example.tran: 不过，泰斯曼付出了代价才得到这些宝贵的信息。

entry.def: If there is a price on someone's head, an amount of money has been offered for the capture or killing of that person.

example.ex: He remains at large despite the high price put on his head by the authorities.
example.tran: 尽管当局悬赏重金缉拿他，他仍旧逍遥法外。

entry.def: If you say that you cannot put a price on something, you mean that it is very valuable.

example.ex: You can't put a price on friendship...
You can't put a price on the value of the work done by our nurses.
example.tran: 不能用金钱来衡量护士的工作。

entry.def: You use what price in front of a word or expression that refers to something happening when you want to ask how likely it is to happen. You usually do this to emphasize either that it is very likely or very unlikely.

example.ex: What price a glorious repeat of last week's triumph?
example.tran: 还有可能再次上演上周的辉煌胜利吗？

entry.def: You use 'at what price ?' to comment on the fact that the consequences of doing something are unpleasant.

example.ex: Yes, they are free of him, but at what price to themselves, their families, those left behind?...
example.tran: 是的，他们离开了他，但是对他们自己、他们的家人以及那些留下来的人又有什么用呢？

means.word_mean: 1. the amount of money needed to purchase something;

sentences.sentence: "he got his new car on excellent terms"

means.word_mean: 2. the property of having material worth (often indicated by the amount of money something would bring if sold);

sentences.sentence: "the fluctuating monetary value of gold and silver"
"he puts a high price on his services"
"he couldn't calculate the cost of the collection"

means.word_mean: 3. value measured by what must be given or done or undergone to obtain something;

sentences.sentence: "the cost in human life was enormous"
"the price of success is hard work"

means.word_mean: 4. the high value or worth of something;
5. a reward for helping to catch a criminal;

sentences.sentence: "the cattle thief has a price on his head"
"they say that every politician has a price"

means.word_mean: 2. ascertain or learn the price of;

derivation.yuyuan_name: Middle English: the noun from Old French pris, from Latin pretium 'value, reward'; the verb, a variant (by assimilation to the noun) of earlier prise 'estimate the value of' (see prize). Compare with praise

sentences.en: a price list

sentences.cn: 汽油价格猛涨
sentences.en: ...a sharp increase in the price of petrol...

sentences.cn: 他们盼望着房价上升。
sentences.en: They expected house prices to rise...

sentences.cn: 斯洛文尼亚将为独立付出巨大的代价。
sentences.en: Slovenia will have to pay a high price for independence...

sentences.cn: 这样没命地工作可能要付出代价，也许是健康受损，甚至是离婚。
sentences.en: There may be a price to pay for such relentless activity, perhaps ill health or even divorce...

sentences.cn: 这些股票的价格可能会定在330便士左右。
sentences.en: The shares are expected to be priced at about 330p...

sentences.cn: Digital公司新产品的定价比同类主机的一半还要低。
sentences.en: Digital priced the new line at less than half the cost of comparable mainframes...

sentences.cn: 如果他们无论如何都想达成交易，他们就得承担其后果。
sentences.en: If they wanted a deal at any price, they would have to face the consequences...

sentences.cn: 我们显然也希望看到人质回家，但并不是不惜任何代价。
sentences.en: We obviously want to see the hostages home, but not at any price.

sentences.cn: 大多数商品都有售，但是价格极高。
sentences.en: Most goods are available, but at a price.

sentences.cn: 出名是有代价的。
sentences.en: Fame comes at a price...

sentences.cn: 不过，泰斯曼付出了代价才得到这些宝贵的信息。
sentences.en: Theismann's precious information came at a price, however.

sentences.cn: 尽管当局悬赏重金缉拿他，他仍旧逍遥法外。
sentences.en: He remains at large despite the high price put on his head by the authorities.

sentences.cn: 友谊无价。
sentences.en: You can't put a price on friendship...

sentences.cn: 不能用金钱来衡量护士的工作。
sentences.en: You can't put a price on the value of the work done by our nurses.

sentences.cn: 还有可能再次上演上周的辉煌胜利吗？
sentences.en: What price a glorious repeat of last week's triumph?

sentences.cn: 是的，他们离开了他，但是对他们自己、他们的家人以及那些留下来的人又有什么用呢？
sentences.en: Yes, they are free of him, but at what price to themselves, their families, those left behind?...

sentences.cn: 成功了又如何？
sentences.en: What price success!

sentences.en: to charge a high/reasonable/low price for sth

sentences.en: rising/falling prices

sentences.cn: 过去这几年，电脑的价格大大降低，简直令人惊讶。
sentences.en: It's amazing how much computers have come down in price over the past few years.

sentences.cn: 我们比较了多种型号的价格以后才买了这一款。
sentences.en: We priced various models before buying this one.

sentences.cn: 汽油价格猛涨
sentences.en: ...a sharp increase in the price of petrol...

sentences.cn: 这些股票的价格可能会定在330便士左右。
sentences.en: The shares are expected to be priced at about 330p...

sentences.cn: 大多数商品都有售，但是价格极高。
sentences.en: Most goods are available, but at a price.

sentences.cn: 有超过二十四家公司直接向公众出售基因检测服务，收费价格从几百美元到2500多美元不等。
sentences.en: More than two dozen companies sell DNA tests Directly to the public , ranging in price from a few hundred dollars to more than $2500.

sentences.cn: 在评估一批资产时，这些准则要求他们必须使用第三方愿意支付的价格，而非以经理人和监管机构期望他们能够售得的价格。
sentences.en: These rules say they must value some assets at the price a third party would pay, not the price managers and regulators would like them to fetch.

sentences.cn: 除非银行以吸引买家的价格将有毒资产卖出，否则，他们将很难重新恢复银行系统。
sentences.en: And, unless banks carry toxic assets at prices that attract buyers, reviving the banking system will be difficult.

sentences.cn: 时至今日，银行辩解道，是市场价格夸大了他们的损失。这是因为，市场价格在很大程度上反映了市场临时的非流动性，而非坏账可能达到的程度。
sentences.en: Today they argue that market prices overstate losses, because they largely reflect the temporary illiquidity of markets not the likely extent of bad debts.

sentences.cn: 同样，自动化会最终提高生产效率，通过压低价格来刺激消费需求，并将工人从乏味辛苦的工作中解放出来。
sentences.en: Likewise, automation should eventually boost productivity, stimulate demand by driving down prices, and free workers from hard, boring work.

sentences.cn: 专家估计这次下滑使艺术品价值较之其峰值平均下降了约40%，不过有些艺术品价格的波动幅度更大。
sentences.en: This time experts reckon that prices are about 40% down on their peak on average, though some have been far more volatile.

sentences.cn: 假若公司面临灭顶之灾，股票价格大跌，外部董事应能基于自身应付危机的经验向公司提出建议。
sentences.en: If the sky, and the share price is falling, outside directors should be able to give advice based on having weathered their own crises.

sentences.cn: 不过越来越多的说法是，源于可再生能源的价格暴跌，尤其是风能和太阳能。
sentences.en: But increasingly the story is about the plummeting prices of renewables, especially wind and solar.

sentences.cn: 去年在一些地区，每公吨肥料的价格飙升了近50%，因此人体粪便成了一种颇具吸引力的替代肥料，而且往往是必不可少的替代选择。
sentences.en: With fertilizer prices jumping nearly 50% per metric ton over the last year in some places, human waste is an attractive, and often necessary, alternative.
sentences.from: 16年6月六级真题（第二套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 政策的制定者不应该让能源的低廉价格阻碍社会向清洁能源转型。
sentences.en: Policymakers should not allow low energy prices to derail the clean energy transition.
sentences.from: 17年6月六级真题（第一套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 煤炭和天然气主要用于发电，而石油主要用于交通运输，但这三类能源的价格是相互联系的
sentences.en: Coal and natural gas are mainly used for electricity generation, whereas oil is used mostly to power transportation, yet the prices of all these energy sources are linked.
sentences.from: 17年6月六级真题（第一套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 不幸的是，油、气、煤目前的低廉价格可能很难鼓励人们探索更加廉价的替代品来取代这些燃料。
sentences.en: Unfortunately, the current low prices for oil, gas, and coal may provide little incentive for research to find even cheaper substitutes for those fuels.
sentences.from: 17年6月六级真题（第一套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 有力证据表明，清洁能源技术的革新与使用都会被更高的化石燃料价格大力推动。
sentences.en: There is strong evidence that both innovation and adoption of cleaner technology are strongly encouraged by higher fossil fuel prices.
sentences.from: 17年6月六级真题（第一套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 这样，目前化石燃料价格低廉的环境必然会给从化石燃料到清洁能源的能源转型拖后腿。
sentences.en: The current low fossil fuel price environment will thus certainly delay the energy transition from fossil fuel to clean energy sources.
sentences.from: 17年6月六级真题（第一套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 由于没有邮费和配送费，所以可以保证价格低廉。
sentences.en: There are no postage or delivery costs, so prices can be kept low
sentences.from: 15年12月六级真题（第一套）| 听力

sentences.cn: 两者价格差不多，都在40美元以下。
sentences.en: Both are similarly priced, and just under $40.
sentences.from: 18年6月六级真题(第二套)| 听力

sentences.cn: 确实，即使在 2008 年粮食价格急剧攀升前，行将就木的国家就在增多。
sentences.en: Indeed, even before the steep climb in grain prices in 2008, the  number  of  failing  states  was  expanding.
sentences.from: 16年6月四级真题（第一套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 2007 年和 2008 年世界粮食价格的激增——以及价格激增对粮食安全造成的威胁——与过去的价格增长性质不同，更令人担忧。
sentences.en: The  surge  in  world  grain  prices  in  2007  and 2008—and  the  threat  they  pose  to  food  security—has  a different,  more  troubling  quality  than  the  increases  of the  past.
sentences.from: 16年6月四级真题（第一套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 20 世纪后半叶，粮食价格出现过好几次急剧上涨。
sentences.en: During  the  second  half  of  the  20th  century, grain  prices  rose  dramatically  several  times.
sentences.from: 16年6月四级真题（第一套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 结果，其他地区的小麦价格上涨，比原来的两倍还高，使得大米和玉米的价格也随之增长。
sentences.en: As  a result, wheat prices elsewhere more than doubled, pulling rice and corn prices up with them.
sentences.from: 16年6月四级真题（第一套）| 阅读

sentences.cn: 另一方面,错付信任通常要承担高昂的代价。

sentences.cn: 最终他被迫供认不讳,并面临判刑, 感到他要无愧于心,其代价再昂贵也是值得的.
sentences.en: In the end he was driven to confess and face a prison sentence, feeling that to clear his conscience would be cheap at the price.

sentences.en: She left and she paid the ultimate price for daring to do so.

sentences.en: Most of the idle rich suffer unspeakable boredom as the price of their freedom from drudgery.

sentences.cn: 该国为独立付出了沉重的代价.
sentences.en: The country paid a heavy price for her independence.

sentences.cn: 第二, 银行将不得不承担开动经济发动机的部分代价.
sentences.en: Second, the bank will be able not but to undertake the start economical engine's partial prices.

sentences.en: Then you may ask the price about the cloth , and sooner the salesman responds.

sentences.cn: 重复的任务和没有突破,必将推动人民要付出沉重的健康代价.
sentences.en: Repetitive tasks and no break will propel people to pay a hefty health price.

sentences.cn: “那你准备好要付出要求的代价了 吗 ?”.

sentences.cn: 抑郁症也许是生活在生机勃勃社会中所要付出的一种不可避免的代价.
sentences.en: Depression may turn out to be an inevitable price of living in a dynamic society.

sentences.cn: 吾人事事都想成功就得付出代价——工作.

sentences.cn: 小仙人又问: “你准备要付出代价了 吗 ?”

To lower domestic food prices, some countries limited or stopped their grain exports.

The trend began in 2007, when leading wheat-exporting countries such as Russia and Argentina limited or banned their exports, in hopes of increasing local food supplies and thereby bringing down domestic food prices.
The surge in world grain prices in 2007 and 2008—and the threat they pose to food security—has a different, more troubling quality than the increases of the past.
The more recent steep climb in grain prices partly results from the fact that more and more people want to consume meat products.
Indeed, even before the steep climb in grain prices in 2008, the number of failing states was expanding.
In spite of such temporary measures, soaring food prices and spreading hunger in many other countries are beginning to break down the social order.
In contrast, the recent surge in world grain prices is trend-driven, making it unlikely to reverse without a reversal in the trends themselves.
During the second half of the 20th century, grain prices rose dramatically several times.
But this and other price shocks were event-driven—drought in the Soviet Union, crop-shrinking heat in the U.S.Corn Belt.
As a result, wheat prices elsewhere more than doubled, pulling rice and corn prices up with them.
And the rises were short-lived: prices typically returned to normal with the next harvest.
They reduce production drastically to boost oil prices.
The reasons behind the plunge of oil prices.
The effect of falling oil prices on consumer spending.
Sara Johnson acknowledges that the global economic benefit from a fall in oil prices today is likely lower than it was in the past.
People the world over are afraid of a further plunge in oil prices.
One reason is that more countries are big oil producers now, so the nations suffering from the price drop account for a larger share of the global economy.
Oil prices may rise or fall but economic laws are not subject to change.
Many oil producers built up huge reserve funds when prices were high, so when prices fall they will draw on their reserves to support government spending and subsidies ( ' ,  补贴) for their consumers.
Lower oil prices have always given a big boost to the global economy.
In the past, falling oil prices have given a boost to the world economy, but recent forecasts for global growth have been toned down, even as oil prices sink lower and lower.
In Venezuela, collapsing oil prices have sent its economy into free-fall.
Economist Carl Weinberg believes the negative effects of plunging oil prices are overwhelming the positive effects of cheaper oil.
Does that mean the link between lower oil prices and growth has weakened?Some experts say there are still good reasons to believe cheap oil should heat up the world economy.
Both options were priced the same.
And a number of oil-producing countries are trimming their gasoline subsidies and raising taxes, so the net savings for global consumers is not as big as the oil price plunge might suggest.
